metadata.titleEn: The soil moisture dataset of China based on microwave data assimilation (2002-2011)
metadata.description:
The soil moisture data set of China based on microwave data assimilation contains three layers of soil moisture data (0-5 cm, 5-20 cm, and 20-100 cm) from 2002 to 2011. The data adopted the automatically calibrating parameters land data assimilation system (ITPLDAS) developed by Yang et al. (2007), the land surface process model SiB2 was then driven by the high spatiotemporal resolution ground meteorological element data set (ITP-forcing data set) in China, the brightness temperature observed by the AMSR-E satellite was assimilated, and, finally, three layers of soil moisture data were obtained. Soil moisture content accuracy: ± 5% VWC (evaluation accuracy of Naqu and Maqu on the Tibetan Plateau).
Data file name:
Soil-Moisture_from_ITPLDAS_daily_0.25deg_v2.1.nc
Description of data content variables:
The file mainly consists of five variables: lon, lat, lev, time and www;
www (time, lev, lat, and lon) is the soil moisture content (missing value: -999.0), where lon, lat, lev, and time are the four dimensions of longitude, latitude, depth and time, respectively;
Variable unit description:
Soil water volume content (www): m3/m3
p.s: The ncdump –h command can be used to directly view the head file information.

background: Soil moisture regulates water, energy and carbon exchanges between land and atmosphere, especially in transitional (semi-arid and semi-humid) regions, and thus it is defined as one of Global Climate Observing System (GCOS) essential climate variables. Soil moisture is a key component in hydro-meteorological forecasting and seasonal climate prediction. Anomalies of spring soil moisture in East Asia may affect summer monsoon circulations and precipitation through changing land surface energy budget. Moreover, soil moisture is crucial to the formation of flood and drought events and is highly concerned in agriculture and ecosystem management. Currently, there are regional or global soil moisture products, but it is still challenging to improve their accuracy. Land surface modeling is widely used to estimate soil moisture values, but the accuracy of the modeling highly depends on model structure, model parameter specification, and meteorological forcing data. Human activities (such as irrigation) may also magnify errors in land surface simulations. On the other hand, there is a long history to estimate soil moisture values from passive microwave signals. A number of evaluations show that both land surface modeling and microwave remote sensing may have considerable biases in soil moisture. Land data assimilation technique is considered a better way to estimate soil moisture through optimally using the dynamics of land surface modeling and the objectivity of satellite remote sensing.
research objective: In this study, a ten-year (2002 – 2011) daily soil moisture dataset at 0.25° spatial resolution for Mainland China was produced through assimilating the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) brightness temperature data into a land surface model. The main purpose of this study is to present the development and validation of a new soil moisture product. In this study, a new soil moisture product for Mainland China was produced through assimilating the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer (AMSR-E) brightness temperature (TB) data in a land surface model. With the new product, the spatiotemporal variability of soil moisture in Mainland China was investigated.
challenges: Establishing soil moisture data sets through a land data assimilation system (LDAS) involves many challenges, such as how to specify model parameter values, how to develop reliable meteorological forcing and how to obtain ground truth for validations at pixel scales. Particularly, inappropriate parameter values in model operator (a land surface model) or observation operator (e.g. a forward radiative transfer model) lead to systematic deviations in assimilation results. In the WTP-Ngari network, both the assimilation result and the LSM-simulation one show the dry feature of this area, but the former does not perform better than the latter. Therefore, it is still challenging to improve soil moisture estimates for drylands with the LDAS.
methods: The LDAS was run at 0.25 degree in the Mainland China, and the assimilation covers the whole period of AMSR-E (June 2002 – September 2011) so that we provided nearly 10-year data of soil moisture. In Pass 1, the values of key parameters (i.e. soil porosity, sand content, clay content, two roughness parameters (Q, h) and one vegetation optical parameter (b) for microwave radiative transfer) are assumed to be time-invariant and estimated through minimizing the difference between the AMSR-E observed TB and the LDAS-estimated TB over a long-term window. In Pass 2, the estimated parameter values are used as inputs of the LDAS, and the near-surface soil moisture (volumetric water content) is estimated through assimilating the AMSR-E TB on a daily scale. The LDAS assimilates the TB data at three lower frequencies (6.9, 10.7, and 18.7 GHz) measured during the descending overpasses, since TB at the lower frequencies are more sensitive to soil moisture than the ones at the higher frequencies. In general, soil moisture has high spatial variability. The LDAS output represents an average at a quarter degree grid, which cannot be validated with single-point measurements. In this study, soil moisture data collected at three observational networks in the Tibetan Plateau were used to validate the LDAS estimate.
dataset: In this study, a ten-year (2002 – 2011) daily soil moisture dataset at 0.25° spatial resolution for Mainland China was produced through assimilating the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) brightness temperature data into a land surface model. The meteorological data used to drive the LDAS is the China Meteorological Forcing Data (CMFD) that was developed by the authors. The CMFD covers the Mainland China with a spatial resolution of 0.1° and spans from 1979 to 2018 with a temporal resolution of 3 hours. The AMSR-E sensor worked from June 2002 to September 2011, and our LDAS yields the soil moisture product for this period. In this study, soil moisture data collected at three observational networks in the Tibetan Plateau were used to validate the LDAS estimate. The LDAS-produced soil moisture product contains three layers (0–5 cm, 5–20 cm, and 20–100 cm) of soil water content, with a unit of m3 m-3. Its temporal resolution is daily and spatial resolution is 0.25°. The data spans from June 2002 to September 2011, covering the Mainland China.
findings: The results show that for the wet areas the accuracy of the soil moisture product obtained from the assimilation is considerably higher than that of both AMSR-E official soil moisture products and land surface simulation results, and for the dry area their accuracy is comparable to each other. The spatial pattern of the soil moisture from the new product is consistent with that of soil porosity from an independent survey-based dataset, further confirming the credibility of the new product. According to this product, the transition regions in China show stronger seasonal variation of soil moisture than dry and wet regions, and drier regions have stronger inter-annual variability of soil moisture than wetter regions, particularly during transitional seasons (spring and autumn). Overall, we can see that assimilating AMSR-E TB into the LSM improves the soil moisture estimation as compared to the remote sensing products and the LSM simulation, particularly for relatively wet areas. Therefore, the LDAS can produce some essential features of soil moisture distribution. This cross-validation indirectly confirms the reasonability of the LDAS-derived soil moisture.

background: Soil moisture is a highly variable parameter in semiarid regions, where strong coupling between soil moisture and precipitation are suggested by Koster et al. (2004). Soil moisture estimation is imperative for hydrometeorological studies and water resources management (e.g., Pauwels et al. 2001; Wu and Dickinson 2004; de Goncalves et al. 2006), and how to estimate soil moisture with good accuracy is still a hot topic of land hydrology and satellite remote sensing. Land hydrological modeling is subject to errors in many factors, including meteorological forcing data, parameterization schemes, and model parameters. Remote sensing of passive microwave has been widely used to estimate soil moisture (e.g., Jackson 1993; Njoku and Entekhabi 1996; Shi et al. 1997; Njoku et al. 2003; Wen et al. 2003, 2005), as it is strongly affected by near-surface soil moisture but not much by atmospheric state. Microwave signals are also affected by other parameters, such as soil texture and surface roughness (Engman 1991); these parameters must be specified for estimating soil moisture from microwave data (Wang 1983; Wigneron et al. 2003; Njoku and Chan 2006). A land data assimilation system (LDAS), which combines a land surface model (LSM) and satellite signals, may provide a promising means for estimating soil moisture by assimilating microwave data to correct modeling errors (Reichle et al. 2001; Bach and Mauser 2003; Crow and Wood 2003; Ni-Meister et al. 2006; Li et al. 2007). The parameter specification is a common and crucial issue for land modeling, remote sensing, and data assimilation. Another common issue is how to make a full scale–match comparison between satellite-estimated soil moisture and in situ–observed soil moisture.
research objective: In response to the aforementioned two issues, this study evaluates the output of the land data assimilation system of The University of Tokyo (LDAS-UT) against measurements from a soil moisture network in a semiarid region.
methods: In this study, near-surface soil moisture data used for validation are measurements at 3-cm depth of 12 ASSH and four AWS [Bayantsagaan (BTS), Delgertsogt site (DGS), Deren site (DRS), and Madalgobi site (MGS)], and meteorological data from the four AWSs are used to drive the LDAS-UT. LDAS-UT is applied to each ASSH station, driven by the averaged AWS data and assimilating AMSR-E 0.18 gridded data. The LSM was run again with the LDAS-UT–calibrated parameters. LDAS-UT and the LSM are driven with AWS, GLDAS, and JMA data. LDAS-UT is driven with AWS data, except that precipitation is taken from one of AWS, GLDAS, and JMA. LDAS-UT is applied to the 12 ASSH stations. The forcing data is averaged at the four AWSs, but downward radiations are taken from Global Land Data Assimilation System (GLDAS; Rodell et al. 2004) 183 18 data, because they were not measured through AMPEX.
dataset: Validation data of soil moisture were collected in a Mongolian semiarid region. The soil moisture network of interest in this study was established by Kaihotsu (2005) in Mongolia through the Advanced Earth Observing Satellite II (ADEOS-II) Mongolian Plateau.
findings: Results show that (i) the LDAS-estimated soil moistures are comparable to areal averages of in situ measurements, though the measured soil moistures were highly variable from site to site; (ii) the LSM-simulated soil moistures show less biases when the LSM uses LDAS-calibrated parameter values instead of default parameter values, indicating that the satellite-based calibration does contribute to soil moisture estimations; and (iii) compared to the LSM, the LDAS produces more robust and reliable soil moisture when forcing data become worse. The lower sensitivity of the LDAS output to precipitation is particularly encouraging for applying this system to regions where precipitation data are prone to errors.

Definition.Question: What does 'land data assimilation system (LDAS)' mean in the context of soil moisture data collection?
Definition.Answer: A land data assimilation system (LDAS) refers to a method that combines a land surface model with satellite signals to estimate soil moisture by assimilating microwave data to correct modeling errors. It involves specifying model parameters and developing reliable meteorological forcing to improve soil moisture estimates.

Definition.Question: What are 'Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) brightness temperature data' in terms of data collection for soil moisture estimation?
Definition.Answer: AMSR-E brightness temperature data are satellite-observed microwave signals that are sensitive to near-surface soil moisture and used in soil moisture estimation. These data are assimilated into land surface models to produce soil moisture datasets with improved accuracy.

Definition.Question: What is the significance of 'soil moisture validation' in data collection and dataset development?
Definition.Answer: Soil moisture validation involves comparing estimated soil moisture values from datasets with in-situ measurements to ensure accuracy and credibility. It is crucial for confirming the reliability of soil moisture products, especially when using data assimilation systems to improve estimates.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of assimilating microwave data into a land surface model for soil moisture estimation compare to traditional land surface modeling techniques in terms of accuracy and challenges?
Comparison.Answer: Assimilating microwave data into a land surface model improves soil moisture estimation accuracy by integrating satellite remote sensing with land modeling, addressing biases present in both techniques. Traditional land surface modeling depends heavily on model structure and meteorological data, often leading to inaccuracies. In contrast, assimilation techniques face challenges such as parameter specification and validation at pixel scales, but they provide more reliable results, especially in wet areas.

Comparison.Question: How does the spatial resolution of soil moisture datasets impact the comparison between satellite-derived and model-assimilated soil moisture products?
Comparison.Answer: The spatial resolution of soil moisture datasets, such as the 0.25° resolution used in model-assimilated products, can significantly affect comparisons. Model-assimilated products, which average data over larger grid areas, may not capture fine-scale variability as well as higher-resolution satellite-derived products. However, the model-assimilated datasets tend to provide a more balanced representation by correcting biases inherent in both satellite data and land surface models, leading to improved reliability in broader spatial patterns.

Interpretation.Question: How can the integration of land surface modeling with microwave remote sensing improve the accuracy of soil moisture datasets, particularly in transitional climate regions?
Interpretation.Answer: The integration of land surface modeling with microwave remote sensing, such as through a land data assimilation system (LDAS), leverages the dynamics of land surface modeling and the objectivity of satellite remote sensing. This combination can enhance the accuracy of soil moisture datasets by minimizing biases associated with individual methods. In transitional climate regions, where soil moisture significantly influences water, energy, and carbon exchanges, this integration can provide more reliable estimates of soil moisture by correcting modeling errors with satellite data.

Interpretation.Question: What are the main challenges in developing soil moisture datasets through land data assimilation systems, and how might they be addressed in future research?
Interpretation.Answer: Developing soil moisture datasets through land data assimilation systems involves challenges such as specifying accurate model parameter values, developing reliable meteorological forcing data, and obtaining ground truth for pixel-scale validations. Inappropriate parameter values can lead to systematic deviations in assimilation results. Future research could address these challenges by improving parameter estimation techniques, utilizing more accurate meteorological data, and enhancing ground truth validation networks.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential advantages of using a land data assimilation system over traditional land surface models for soil moisture estimation in semi-arid regions?
Interpretation.Answer: A land data assimilation system (LDAS) provides advantages over traditional land surface models by incorporating satellite microwave data to correct modeling errors and reduce biases. In semi-arid regions, where soil moisture is highly variable, LDAS can produce more robust and reliable soil moisture estimates, especially when meteorological forcing data is less accurate. It also offers lower sensitivity to precipitation errors, making it particularly useful in regions where precipitation data are prone to inaccuracies.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes systematic deviations in soil moisture data assimilation results using land data assimilation systems (LDAS)?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Systematic deviations in soil moisture data assimilation results using LDAS can be caused by inappropriate parameter values in the model operator, such as a land surface model, or observation operator, like a forward radiative transfer model. Additionally, errors may arise from challenges in specifying model parameter values, developing reliable meteorological forcing, and obtaining ground truth for validations at pixel scales.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is it challenging to improve the accuracy of soil moisture estimates in drylands using data assimilation techniques?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Improving the accuracy of soil moisture estimates in drylands using data assimilation techniques is challenging because both the assimilation results and the land surface model simulations may not perform better than each other in dry areas. Factors such as parameter specification and the inherent dry features of these regions contribute to the difficulty in enhancing accuracy.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential outcomes of using a land data assimilation system (LDAS) to integrate satellite remote sensing data with land surface models in soil moisture estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using a land data assimilation system (LDAS) to integrate satellite remote sensing data with land surface models can lead to improved soil moisture estimation by leveraging both the dynamic modeling capabilities of land surface models and the objectivity of satellite remote sensing. This approach has shown to enhance accuracy, particularly in wet areas, and provides a more robust soil moisture product that reflects essential features of soil moisture distribution.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the application of passive microwave signals influence the accuracy of soil moisture data collection in transitional regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Passive microwave signals, when applied in soil moisture data collection, can influence accuracy by being directly affected by near-surface soil moisture levels. This method offers an objective way to estimate soil moisture and can capture strong seasonal variations and inter-annual variability in transitional regions, such as semi-arid and semi-humid areas, which are crucial for understanding water, energy, and carbon exchanges between land and atmosphere.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the possible consequences of parameter specification errors in soil moisture estimation using land surface models and remote sensing data?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Parameter specification errors in soil moisture estimation using land surface models and remote sensing data may lead to systematic deviations in the assimilation results. These errors can affect the reliability of the soil moisture estimates, particularly in drylands where the estimation challenges are greater. Proper calibration of parameters is crucial to minimize these biases and enhance the accuracy of soil moisture products.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of using land data assimilation systems (LDAS) in the estimation of soil moisture in transitional climate regions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective of using LDAS in soil moisture estimation is to optimally combine the dynamics of land surface modeling and the objectivity of satellite remote sensing to improve the accuracy of soil moisture data, particularly in transitional climate regions where soil moisture plays a crucial role in water, energy, and carbon exchanges between land and atmosphere.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to validate soil moisture datasets produced through remote sensing and land surface modeling with observational network data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to validate soil moisture datasets with observational network data to ensure accuracy and reliability, especially considering that both land surface modeling and microwave remote sensing might have considerable biases. Validation helps confirm the credibility of soil moisture estimates and improves the reliability of the datasets for applications in hydrometeorological forecasting and climate prediction.

Goal Orientation.Question: What goals motivate the integration of Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer (AMSR-E) brightness temperature data into land surface models for soil moisture product development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The integration of AMSR-E brightness temperature data into land surface models aims to enhance the spatiotemporal variability understanding of soil moisture, create a more accurate soil moisture product, and investigate soil moisture dynamics across different regions. This integration seeks to address challenges in parameter specification and improve soil moisture estimates by leveraging satellite remote sensing data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can passive microwave signals be utilized in a land data assimilation system to improve soil moisture estimation?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Passive microwave signals can be utilized in a land data assimilation system by assimilating brightness temperature data from sensors like AMSR-E into a land surface model. This involves calibrating key parameters such as soil porosity, sand content, clay content, and vegetation optical parameters to minimize differences between observed and estimated brightness temperatures. The assimilation is performed at specific frequencies that are sensitive to soil moisture, and the output represents an averaged soil moisture estimation over a defined spatial grid.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are involved in validating soil moisture estimates obtained from a land data assimilation system using observational networks?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The validation process involves comparing the soil moisture estimates from the land data assimilation system with ground truth data collected from observational networks. In the context of the dataset, soil moisture data from three observational networks in the Tibetan Plateau were used for validation. The assimilation results are then evaluated against in situ measurements to assess accuracy, particularly focusing on spatial averages over a grid rather than single-point measurements.

Enablement.Question: What conditions and technological approaches have enabled the assimilation of microwave data to improve soil moisture estimation in semiarid regions?
Enablement.Answer: The assimilation of microwave data into a land surface model is enabled by a combination of technological approaches, such as using the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) brightness temperature data and employing a Land Data Assimilation System (LDAS). This involves calibrating model parameters and integrating satellite signals to correct modeling errors, which is particularly useful in semiarid regions where soil moisture and precipitation exhibit strong coupling.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements have facilitated the development of soil moisture datasets with high spatial and temporal resolution for regions like Mainland China?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements such as the development of the China Meteorological Forcing Data (CMFD) and the use of AMSR-E satellite data have facilitated the creation of soil moisture datasets with high spatial (0.25°) and temporal (daily) resolution. The CMFD provides comprehensive meteorological data to drive land surface models, while the AMSR-E data allows for the assimilation of brightness temperatures to enhance soil moisture estimates across Mainland China.

Expectation.Question: Why might the accuracy of soil moisture estimates for drylands be challenging despite using a land data assimilation system?
Expectation.Answer: The accuracy of soil moisture estimates for drylands can be challenging due to inappropriate parameter values in both the model operator and observation operator, leading to systematic deviations in assimilation results. Moreover, the assimilation system might not perform better than land surface model simulations in dry feature areas, indicating the difficulty in improving estimates in such regions.

Expectation.Question: Why is it difficult to achieve full scale–match comparisons between satellite-estimated soil moisture and in situ–observed soil moisture?
Expectation.Answer: Achieving full scale–match comparisons between satellite-estimated soil moisture and in situ–observed soil moisture is difficult because the land data assimilation system output represents an average at a grid scale, which cannot be directly validated with single-point measurements. The spatial variability of soil moisture adds to the complexity of making accurate comparisons.

Expectation.Question: Why is the land data assimilation system considered a promising approach for soil moisture estimation in regions with unreliable precipitation data?
Expectation.Answer: The land data assimilation system is considered promising for soil moisture estimation in regions with unreliable precipitation data because it produces more robust and reliable soil moisture outputs with less sensitivity to precipitation inaccuracies, thereby allowing for better performance under suboptimal data conditions.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of using passive microwave signals for soil moisture estimation compared to other remote sensing techniques?
Judgmental.Answer: Passive microwave signals have a long history of being used for soil moisture estimation because they are strongly affected by near-surface soil moisture and not as much by atmospheric state. However, they can be influenced by other parameters such as soil texture and surface roughness, which need to be specified accurately for effective estimation.

Judgmental.Question: What are the major challenges faced in specifying model parameter values for land data assimilation systems, and how might these challenges affect soil moisture data accuracy?
Judgmental.Answer: One major challenge in specifying model parameter values for land data assimilation systems is ensuring that both the model operator and observation operator are accurate. Inappropriate parameter values can lead to systematic deviations in assimilation results, which can affect the accuracy of soil moisture data, particularly in drylands.

Judgmental.Question: In your opinion, how does assimilating satellite data into land surface models improve soil moisture estimates, and what are the limitations of this approach?
Judgmental.Answer: Assimilating satellite data into land surface models can improve soil moisture estimates by optimally using the dynamics of land surface modeling and the objectivity of satellite remote sensing. However, this approach may still have limitations, such as the inability to perform better in dry areas compared to land surface simulations, and challenges in obtaining ground truth for validations at pixel scales.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the data collection techniques used in creating a soil moisture dataset through land data assimilation systems, focusing on the integration of satellite data and land surface models.
Request/Directive.Answer: The data collection techniques involve using a land data assimilation system (LDAS) that integrates satellite data, specifically the Advanced Microwave Scanning Radiometer for Earth Observing System (AMSR-E) brightness temperature data, with a land surface model. The LDAS runs at a 0.25-degree spatial resolution and covers the period from June 2002 to September 2011. It utilizes meteorological forcing data, such as the China Meteorological Forcing Data (CMFD), to drive the model and assimilates the brightness temperature data at three lower frequencies (6.9, 10.7, and 18.7 GHz) from the AMSR-E sensor, which are sensitive to soil moisture, to estimate volumetric water content at different soil depths.

Request/Directive.Question: Please identify the challenges faced in developing a reliable soil moisture dataset using microwave remote sensing and land surface models, and discuss how these challenges are addressed.
Request/Directive.Answer: Challenges in developing a reliable soil moisture dataset include specifying accurate model parameter values, developing reliable meteorological forcing data, and obtaining ground truth for validations at pixel scales. Inappropriate parameter values in the model or observation operators can lead to systematic deviations in assimilation results. These challenges are addressed by estimating key parameters, such as soil porosity and surface roughness, through minimizing the difference between observed and estimated brightness temperatures over a long-term window. Additionally, validation of the LDAS estimates is conducted using soil moisture data collected at observational networks to ensure accuracy.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore potential datasets or methods for validating soil moisture estimates produced by data assimilation systems, particularly in semi-arid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Potential datasets for validating soil moisture estimates include measurements from soil moisture networks established in semi-arid regions, such as those used in the Mongolian Plateau. Methods for validation involve comparing the LDAS-estimated soil moistures with areal averages of in situ measurements, despite site-to-site variability. The use of satellite-based calibration for land surface models also aids in improving soil moisture estimations, and the LDAS's lower sensitivity to errors in precipitation data makes it suitable for application in regions with unreliable precipitation data.
